newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: EMU DEBATE TO BE FOCUS AT DAVOS FORUM - OFFICIALS.
newsitem.headline: EMU DEBATE TO BE FOCUS AT DAVOS FORUM - OFFICIALS.

text.p: Discussion on European Monetary Union will be a key theme at this year's World Economic Forum of political and business leaders in Davos, officials said.
"The common currency and its chances for implementation will come up at a number of sessions," Forum Executive Director Claude Smajda told reporters.

Key figures taking part in the Forum from January 30 to February 4 will include European Commission President Jacques Santer, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke and Spain's Finance Minister Rodrigo Rato.
Also there will be French Economy and Finance Minister Jean Arthuis, Belgium's Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene, and German Finance Minister Theo Waigel, Smajda told a news conference.
Among leading European bankers taking part in Forum sessions would be Jean-Claude Trichet, Governor of the Bank of France, Howard Davies, Deputy Governor of the Bank of England.
German Bundesbank President Hans Tietmayer, a regular figure at the annual gathering of world business and political leaders, will not be going this year because of a scheduling problem, Smajda said.
But he would be replaced by his deputy, Johann-Wilhelm Gaddum. Also there would be Philippe Maystadt, Finance and External Trade Minister of Belgium.
Smajda said the discussions would focus on the timetable and the "likely realisation" of a single European currency by the 1999 deadline.
Other key financial figures attending the Forum include U.S. Deputy Treasure Secretary Lawrance Summers, and Akira Nagashima, Deputy Governor of the Bank of Japan.
Maystadt and Yves-Thibault de Silguy, European Commissioner in charge of monetary affairs, will take part in a Forum debate on February 1 on the implications of the single currency for business.

Later the same day, Arthuis, Clarke, Dehaene and Rato will form a panel discussing the impact of the single currency on European economic competitiveness on the global stage. (Geneva newsroom - (41-22) 733-38-31).
